Dear Mr. Genwright:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that Supervisor 1 displays inappropriate grooming behaviors towards
female youth by touching them and playing with their hair.
INVESTIGATION:
Youth A
I interviewed Youth A on 08/18/2021 at Saginaw County Detention with another
Department of Child Welfare Licensing staff. Youth A stated Supervisor 1 plays with
hair, Youth B’s hair and Youth D’s hair. Youth A stated Supervisor 1 pointed to her
braids in the cafeteria, touched her braids and said her braids were too tight. Youth
A stated Supervisor 1 also twirled his finger in Youth B’s and Youth D’s hair. Youth A
stated she witnessed Supervisor 1 stick his finger in Youth D’s ear and called her
“fine.” Youth A stated there are no other boundary concerns with staff.
Youth B
I interviewed Youth B on 08/18/2021 at Saginaw County Detention with another
Department of Child Welfare Licensing staff. Youth B stated Supervisor 1 was weird
and a freak when asked to describe him. Youth B stated she sat in front of the
television and Supervisor 1 stood behind her and twirled the back of her hair. Youth
B stated she said, “Stop touching me” and Supervisor 1 walked away. Youth B
stated in another incident Supervisor 1 sat down, put his leg on Youth D’s leg and
stuck his finger in her ear. Youth B stated Supervisor 1 said “You’re fine” to Youth D
and left the unit when staff returned. Youth B stated there was also a boundary
incident in the cafeteria when she sat by Youth A, her twin sister. Youth B stated
Supervisor 1 made fun of them eating and twirled Youth A’s hair before leaving.
Youth B stated Supervisor 1 also tried to twist Youth A’s hair in another incident, but
left when Youth A told him to get away. Youth B stated she recalled another incident
when Supervisor 1 touched Youth D’s two spaced ponytail buns. Youth B stated
Youth C witnessed Supervisor 1’s boundary incidents.
Youth C
I interviewed Youth C on 08/18/2021 at Saginaw County Detention with another
Department of Child Welfare Licensing staff. Youth C stated Supervisor 1 takes his
job seriously and does not come to the unit much, but completes tours of the units
and the cafeteria. Youth C stated Supervisor 1 talks to the female youths more than
the male youths. Youth C stated he did not have boundary concerns with Supervisor
1 and is unaware of any youth having boundary issues with Supervisor 1. Youth C
stated he did not know of boundary issues with Youth A, Youth B and Youth D.
Youth D
I spoke with Youth’s D’s mother on 09/13/2021 and explained Department of Child
Welfare Licensing and the allegation. Youth D’s mother stated Youth D would be
available 09/14/2021 for a telephone interview. I called on 09/14/2021 and Youth D
was not available. Youth D’s mother stated Youth D told her that she did not know
anything. Youth D’s mother stated to call Youth D at her grandmother’s house since
she was now staying there. I attempted to reach Youth D on 09/14/2021, 09/15/2021
3

and 09/17/2021. Each time an automated response stated the call cannot be
completed.
Supervisor 1
I interviewed Supervisor 1 on 08/18/2021 at Saginaw County Detention with another
Department of Child Welfare Licensing staff. Supervisor 1 stated he knows Youth A
and Youth B, but cannot tell the twins apart. Supervisor 1 stated he knew the
purpose of the investigation. Supervisor 1 stated during lunch he approached one of
the twins and touched her braids because he was concerned about contraband
being kept in the braids. Supervisor 1 stated the braids were tight and pulled up
making it possible to store contraband. Supervisor 1 stated the twin said she was
going to take down her braids. Supervisor 1 stated during visits that afternoon he
asked the twins about their braids and told them again their braids had to come
down. Supervisor 1 stated during visits he redirected the twins for straddling their
father in the visit room and the father had his arms wrapped around the twins.
Supervisor 1 stated he redirected them twice for inappropriate physical contact and
was informed after visits that a complaint was filed against him. Supervisor 1 denied
other incidents of touching a youth’s hair on the unit or in the cafeteria. Supervisor 1
denied any incident of sticking his finger in a youth’s ear or putting his leg on the
knee of a youth.
Chief administrator
I interviewed the Chief administrator on 08/18/2021 at Saginaw County Detention
with another Department of Child Welfare Licensing staff. Chief administrator stated
youths are allowed to wear braids and buns and there are not any incidents of
contraband being kept in a youth’s hair.
Video
I reviewed a video footage of 08/05/2021 that shows Supervisor 1 walks up to Youth
D, leans back against a wall, sits down in a chair next to Youth D, raises his right leg
straight to rest on Youth D’s left thigh momentarily and then removes his right leg
and gets up and leaves.
I reviewed a video footage of 08/05/2021 that shows Supervisor 1 is talking face to
face with Youth D and tried to touch her face or mask and then leaves.
I reviewed a video footage of 08/11/2021 that shows Supervisor 1 walks towards
Youth A and places a hand momentarily on her head.
Saginaw County Detention reviewed other recent video footage and did not find
anything else documenting Supervisor 1 with boundary issues.
Personnel file
Supervisor 1 was hired in 07/2003. Supervisor 1 does not have disciplinary action in
the past two years.
4

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.10107 Employment policies and procedures; establishment.
A facility shall establish and follow written employment policies
and procedures that shall assure staff are emotionally stable,
and of suitable health, ability, experience, and education to
perform the duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: Staff person 1 admits to touching either Youth A or Youth B’s
braids out of concern of contraband being kept in the braids.
Chief administrator stated youths are allowed to wear braids and
there is not any incident or concern of contraband being kept in
a youth’s braids. Saginaw County Detention reviewed video
tape and found Supervisor 1 with two incidents of inappropriate
boundary on 08/05/2021 and one incident of inappropriate
boundary on 08/11/2021. It is found that Supervisor 1 crossed
boundaries by touching Youth A’s braids and head, by trying to
touch Youth D’s face or mask and putting his leg on Youth D’s
thigh.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
The continuance of a regular license is recommended upon receipt of an approved
corrective action plan.
